title: LOL offline mode practice against bots with no internet
body: When out and about with the laptop, or power failure no internet or lagging connection LOL offline mode allows people to practise their CS or against bots with no internet.

replies.body: I'd rather they make an appear offline mode...
I would really love this to be a thing, since my internet gets capped pretty fast and I end up playing nothing for 3 weeks straight. My life would be 1% closer to being complete.

Unfortunately most of the League program is server-sided, which mean an offline mode is not possible.
On the good side, it makes cheats and hacks virtually impossible. Glitches and bugs can be exploited, sure, but nobody can set his gold to 999k without cracking a server and giving it to everyone.
Google "Flash Hacks League" and you will see a hack, zero cooldown on flash.

And i'm guessing they show a video of a Singed doing it with smite and flash, right? With a link to the program, and all comments confirming that it works (all the visible ones at least)? :)
Don't click on it, it's a keylogger that will steal your account. That stuff was possible due to a bug with masteries in S3, but it got fixed within the hour, doesn't work anymore... It still caused SO many account recoveries that i stopped counting after a couple months.

As i said, glitches and bugs can be exploited. Until they're fixed, after that they're only good for scamming people.

(bug was as follows:
last utility mastery gave 5% summoner's spell reduction.
masteries were saved locally.
editing the file let you have 20 points in the same mastery, allowing 100%CDR on summoner spells, as long as total mastery points = summoner level
=
any summoner spell had 0 cooldown. you could also do other nice stuff, but that was the simplest.
now:
masteries are server-saved, and cannot be edited)
On what do you base this claim ? This is nonsense, of course it's possible, it's computer science not eternal life or backward time travel or walking naked on the sun.

On League's structure.
Trust me, i know something about it ;) Computer science is not magic.
(also backward time travel is theoretically possible, up to a limit.)
